> This has to do with understanding the role of programmer tests as
> opposed to customer tests. I have some fuzzy ideas in this direction,
> but nothing to make a paper possible yet. The bottom line is
> understanding the importance of blazing fast programmer tests and of
> separating PTs from CTs.

What I did for Xindice (XML Database) is to separate the tests (unit,
integration and stress).  The unit tests run all the time but the integration
tests run less often.

The problem is that Xindice provides several drivers (xml-rpc and embed) to
access the database.  To test the xml-rpc driver, you have to generate the
xindice.war file, copy it into your Tomcat's (e.g.) webapps directory and
reload it.  If you do this each time you make a tiny modification it's quite
painful (and not everyone has a Tomcat server running).  So it was natural to
separate the tests according to their complexity.

if you're interested, you can browse the code
<http://cvs.apache.org/viewcvs.cgi/xml-xindice/java/tests/>

Another question: how would you handle a test that is supposed to pass but that
 currently fails because of a problem you can't fix?  "All the tests must pass
all the time" is fine if you have control over the entire code, but what if one
of the libraries you use has a bug?  While other are fixing the library, your
tests are still broken but it's still ok to commit new code (because no other
new test fail)...

How can you handle the situation?  Removing the failing test (altering its name
for example) is IMO not so clean if you don't have a mechanism to automatically
spot them.
